data.message: Alaa New I'm calling him now already :)
أظن ده طبيعي، على الأقل علشان يعمل preview أو يكتب summary عن اللينك وعنوانه؟ مادام مش عليه authentication يبقى من حق "أي حد" ع النت إنه يقراه ويفهرسه

It is a simple experiment anyway to be repeated
Create a google doc and send it to your friend an see if anonymous user appears

or may be better try to create your own private link and log the IP address of the bot :)

 ده نوع من انواع الخصوصيه بيعتبر ان الـ

هو الباسورد

فده تعدي اكيد من 
Facebook
علي خصوصيتك

I will play the devil advocate here; Facebook needs to read some <meta> tags to generate the preview image/text. And in the case of the Google document being only visible to those who have a URL, Facebook has no way of detecting that; it will try to fetch the document and the document will be fetched.

Sticking around the document beyond reading the tags, however, is a completely different story. But I imagine they would justify that in the same way Google did with using people's Google+ photos: "you handed the document to us, we did not steal it from you".

Assuming that they respect user's privacy. Which I believe they do not. They only care about things that could drag them into court. There is no such thing as "being nice" in corporate world, unfortunately.

This shouldn't be a surprise. FB makes a full GET request to the URL you share or write into a message to generate a preview & do security analysis. In their user agent they put this link https://www.facebook.com/externalhit_uatext.php

As a side note, this tools show you what the Facebook bot sees and does
https://developers.facebook.com/tools/debug
Write a url to see how will Facebook parse it

You can see that your link is allocated its own graph URL just by being shared

it's the same with gmail, they read the text, the attached files, even they read inside the attached zip file , now they use this info for ads , but at least we know there is no such real privacy, as Ahmed T. Al-Amir mentioned , it's just the matter of courts
